conclusion: Consider the forces acting on each object to determine what will happen when objects A and B move through the air and are placed down at the location of objects C, D, E, F.
Identify the forces acting on each object: Objects A and B experience air resistance; Objects C, D, E, F do not.
Calculate the gravitational force acting on each object: Objects A and B experience a downward force due to gravity; Objects C, D, E, F do not experience a downward force due to gravity.
Determine the direction of the force acting on each object: The downward force due to gravity acts downward on both sets of objects.
Calculate the magnitude of the force acting on each object: For objects A and B, it depends on their mass and the acceleration due to gravity; for objects C, D, E, F, it is the same as for A and B.

Determine the net force acting on each object: For objects A and B, it is the sum of the gravitational force and the downward force due to gravity; for objects C, D, E, F, it is the gravitational force.
Determine the direction of the net force acting on each object: It is downward for both sets of objects.

Determine the magnitude of the net force acting on each object: For objects A and B, it is the sum of the gravitational force and the downward force due to gravity; for objects C, D, E, F, it is the gravitational force.
